properties.name: Arch Rock (Arch Rock Trailhead)
properties.notes:
Arch Rock (Arch Rock Trailhead) https://www.nps.gov/places/arch-rock-arch-rock-trailhead.htm

Located along Pinto Basin Road, the Arch Rock and Twin Tanks Trailhead provides access to two popular trails: the Arch Rock Trail and the California Riding and Hiking Trail. 

Arch Rock Trail is a 1.4-mile lollipop loop with a 100 ft elevation gain that leads to the iconic Arch Rock formation. This family-friendly trail is a delightful exploration of Joshua Tree’s unique geological features and offers views of Arch Rock, Whale Rock, and a short detour to Heart Rock. It is an excellent choice for photographers and rock scramblers. While on the trail, see how many other unique rock formations remind you of fun shapes or animals! 

Due to the popularity of this trail, parking can be difficult. On busy days, arrive at the trailhead early to beat the crowds. When crossing the road, please use the crosswalk. Always remember to bring adequate water, food, and sun protection.  

The California Riding and Hiking Trail is accessible from this trailhead and provides opportunities for longer hikes and wilderness backpacking. Permits are required for backpacking in the national park; please check our website for more information.

properties.name: Arch Rock and Twin Tanks Trailhead
properties.notes:
Arch Rock and Twin Tanks Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/arch-rock-and-twin-tanks-trailhead.htm

properties.name: Bajada Trailhead
properties.notes:
Bajada Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/bajada-trailhead.htm

The Bajada Nature Trail is a short, flat, quarter-mile nature trail that meanders through common vegetation found in the Colorado Desert. Along the trail are interpretive signs highlighting different plants and their adaptations and uses. The trail is located near the southern boundary of the park, south of the Cottonwood Visitor Center. It is much lower in elevation than most of the park and offers a unique showcase of plants highly adapted to extreme heat and little rain.

Occasionally, after wet winters, this trail will offer vibrant displays of wildflowers in February and March. For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page. 
 
This trail offers little to no shade so make sure to bring proper sun protection.

properties.name: Barker Dam Trailhead
properties.notes:
Barker Dam Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/barker-dam-trailhead.htm

Barker Dam Nature Trail Trailhead provides access to Barker Dam on an easy 1.1 mile hike. This trail connects to additional trails for longer hikes. The Barker Dam Nature Trail is a mix of compact dirt, granite boulders, and sandy washes. 

Wander through Joshua Tree's iconic monzogranite boulders, namesake Joshua trees, and past the historic Barker Dam. Visit a rock art site and experience human history from a respectful distance.

Encounter rock climbers, spot wildlife big and small, scramble over boulders, and walk along desert washes. Catch a glimpse of the far-off San Gorgonio Mountain. View the plant life of the Mojave Desert, including Joshua trees, creosote, Mojave yucca, pinon pines, and more.

After periods of heavy rainfall, the Barker Dam reservoir will occasionally fill with water. Otherwise, the reservoir is typically dry most of the year.

This trail is ideal for short visits, families, wildlife enthusiasts, rock art and history enthusiasts, photographers, and novice scramblers.

properties.name: Big Trees Trailhead
properties.notes:
Big Trees Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/big-trees-trailhead-at-joshua-tree.htm

Big Trees Trail is a 6 mile (round trip) out-and-back hike less than 100 ft of elevation gain. This trail is great for admiring the desert vegetation and looking out for wildlife. On this hike, you’ll see some of the bigger Joshua trees in the park. Take a moment and see if you can spot a nesting Red Tail Hawk or Scott’s Oriole in the Joshua trees. On the ground, be on the lookout for racing jackrabbits, burrowing ground squirrels, and the occasional lizard bathing in the sun.  

 
Big Trees Trail is also known as the Lost Horse Connector Trail because it connects to Lost Horse Mine Trail. If you continue on the Lost Horse Mine Trail to the historic mining site, then return to the trailhead, it creates a 10 mile (round trip) out-and back hike with approximately 650 feet of elevation gain. If you continue to hike the full Lost Horse Loop Hike, then return to the trailhead, it creates a 12.5 mile “lollipop” loop hike with approximately 900 feet of elevation gain. 

If camping at Ryan Campground, this trail can be accessed from the campground near campsite 13. If not camping, park your car in the Juniper Flats parking lot and start hiking northeast on the California Riding and Hiking Trail until you reach Ryan Campground. From the campground, begin hiking the Big Trees Trail at the trail junction near campsite 13.

properties.name: Bighorn Sheep (Barker Dam Trailhead)
properties.notes:
Bighorn Sheep (Barker Dam Trailhead) https://www.nps.gov/places/bighorn-sheep-barker-dam-trailhead.htm Barker Dam Nature Trail Trailhead provides access to Barker Dam on an easy 1.1 mile hike. This trail connects to additional trails for longer hikes. The Barker Dam Nature Trail is a mix of compact dirt, granite boulders, and sandy washes. 

Wander through Joshua Tree's iconic monzogranite boulders, namesake Joshua trees, and past the historic Barker Dam. Visit a rock art site and experience human history from a respectful distance.

This trail is ideal for short visits, families, wildlife enthusiasts, rock art and history enthusiasts, photographers, and novice scramblers.

properties.name: Black Rock Backcountry Trailhead
properties.notes:
Black Rock Backcountry Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/black-rock-backcountry-trailhead.htm

The Black Rock area of Joshua Tree National Park is isolated and not connected by roads to other areas of the park. Visitors must leave the park through the North or West Entrance and re-enter the park south of Yucca Valley. Plan your driving time accordingly to make the most out of your visit.

Parking is limited in the Black Rock area. Hikers should park at the Backcountry trailhead, the Black Rock Nature Center, or the horse parking area. See the campground map to find parking locations.
The Black Rock Canyon Backcountry Trailhead is the starting point for numerous hikes in the Black Rock area:

  • Panorama Loop (6.6 miles)

  • Warren Peak (6.3 miles)

  • Eureka Peak (11 miles)

  • Burnt Hill (7.3 miles)

  • Short Loop (4 miles)

  • California Riding and Hiking Trail (36.6 miles)


Find detailed information on each trail in the Hiking section on the app's homepage or click here.

properties.name: Boy Scout Trailhead
properties.notes:
Boy Scout Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/boy-scout-trailhead.htm Explore the Wonderland of Rocks on the Boy Scout Trail. The Boy Scout Trail runs for a total of 8 miles one way(16 miles round trip), but hikes of any length can be a great way to experience the Wonderland of Rocks. Start from the Keys West Wilderness Backpacking Board along Park Boulevard and enjoy a hike for as long as you would like.

This trail has little shade and unreliable cell service. Always check the weather forecast before heading into the park and consider changing plans if the weather conditions are too extreme. Before hiking, tell a safety buddy where you are going and when you plan on leaving the park

properties.name: Burnt Hill Trailhead
properties.notes:
Burnt Hill Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/burnt-hill-trailhead.htm

The Burnt Hill Trail travels through the hills of the Black Rock Area and is lined with pinyon trees, Joshua trees, and various shrubs. It is 7.3 miles round trip with 910 feet of elevation gain. It will lead you through a wash, a narrow canyon, and an open valley offering a nice variety of what the Black Rock region has to offer. This trail is great for those camping in the Black Rock area and looking for a longer day hike from their site. 

To make this hike a loop, return on the Eureka Peak Trail. To extend your hike to the top of Eureka Peak, from the junction of the Burnt Hill Trail and Eureka Peak Trail, you can hike 2.4 miles (round trip) to the summit and back to the junction.  

Because this trail is located at a higher elevation than much of the park, it has slightly cooler temperatures on warm days. However, there is very little shade mid-day, so it is not recommended in the summer heat. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection. 

 

There are multiple options for parking. Park at the Black Rock Backcountry Trailhead or park at the Black Rock Nature Center and start the trail near campsite 30. On busy days, there is additional overflow parking in the horse camp area.

properties.name: California Riding and Hiking Trail at Geology Tour Road
properties.notes:
California Riding and Hiking Trail at Geology Tour Road https://www.nps.gov/places/crhgeotour.htm

Take a hike east or west from here on the California Riding and Hiking Trail. Carry water with you. The California Riding and Hiking Trail is 37 miles total, but smaller sections are popular day-hikes. This trailhead is in the middle of the California Riding and Hiking Trail and the trail can be hiked either to the east or west from here.

properties.name: California Riding and Hiking Trailhead
properties.notes:
California Riding and Hiking Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/california-riding-and-hiking-trailhead.htm

The California Riding and Hiking Trail (CRHT) is 36.6 miles and spans from Black Rock Canyon to the North Entrance. It leads hikers through a variety of diverse landscapes in the Mojave Desert section of the park. You can see valleys full of Joshua trees, towering boulder piles, springtime wildflowers, and miles of remote wilderness. 

The CRHT is popular with backpackers and typically takes 2-3 days to complete the entire length. Day hikers can explore shorter sections from multiple trailheads at Black Rock, Upper Covington Flat, Juniper Flats, Geology Tour Road, Twin Tanks/Arch Rock Trailhead, and North Entrance.  

Permits are required for backpacking; please review our website for more information. This trail is not recommended during the summer due to high temperatures and sun exposure. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.

properties.name: Cap Rock
properties.notes:
Cap Rock https://www.nps.gov/places/cap-rock.htm

Cap Rock is a popular rock formation in the central part of Joshua Tree National Park. Located near the north end of Keys View Road near Park Boulevard, Cap Rock is an easy to reach location. In addition to the unique rock formation, Cap Rock offers a picnic area with grills as well as the Cap Rock Nature Trail for a short walk through nearby rock formations with interpretive signs along the way to learn about the area. The area around Cap Rock and the nature trail are flat dirt and gravel surfaces.

properties.name: Cholla Cactus (Cholla Cactus Garden)
properties.notes:
Cholla Cactus (Cholla Cactus Garden) https://www.nps.gov/places/cholla-cactus-cholla-cactus-garden.htm

Stroll through the Cholla Cactus Garden along a flat 0.25-mile loop trail. Hike through thousands of teddy bear cholla cactus and enjoy scenic mountain views. The Cholla Cactus Garden is in the Pinto Basin, part of the transition zone between the Colorado and Mojave Deserts. Cholla are concentrated here because of the right conditions for these plants to thrive and multiply. They mainly reproduce when detached stems root into the ground to grow a new plant. These separate stems are often too heavy for the wind to carry, so the colony grows in this area or "garden"! 

The Cholla Cactus Garden is a unique experience during a visit year-round. It is a great place to enjoy the sunrise or sunset. If you visit in the spring, you will see the yellow/green blooms. 

Tread cautiously around these cacti because they are commonly called "jumping" cholla." The cholla segments can break off and attach to people and animals with sharp spines. Wear closed-toed shoes on this trail to protect your feet. Stay on the designated trail to protect this delicate ecological area.

properties.name: Cholla Cactus Garden
properties.notes:
Cholla Cactus Garden https://www.nps.gov/places/cholla-cactus-garden.htm

properties.name: Contact Mine Trailhead
properties.notes:
Contact Mine Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/contact-mine-trailhead.htm The Contact Mine Trail is an out-and-back hike to a historic mining site. It is 4-miles round trip with 700 feet of elevation gain. The trail begins in a sandy wash then ascends a rocky mountainside to the mine. The hike features expansive views of the surrounding mountains and a chance to view mining artifacts used a century ago. Do not handle or remove any historic artifacts from the site. 

This trail is a great option if you are looking to get away from the crowds and enjoy more solitude. After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. 

For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.

properties.name: Continuing Your Journey (Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center)
properties.notes:
Continuing Your Journey (Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center)
https://www.nps.gov/places/continuing-your-journey-joshua-tree-national-park-visitor-center.htm

The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located in downtown Twentynine Palms and features educational exhibits, a bookstore and giftshop, and visitor information.

properties.name: Cottonwood Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Cottonwood Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/cottonwood-picnic-area.htm

The Cottonwood Picnic Area is located by the group sites in the Cottonwood Campground. This picnic area offers covered picnic tables and grills among scattered small trees and shrubs, providing a place for day visitors to enjoy a meal in the park in the southern portion of the park.

properties.name: Cottonwood Spring
properties.notes:
Cottonwood Spring https://www.nps.gov/places/cottonwood-spring.htm

Cottonwood Spring is a lush desert oasis located in the southern portion of the Joshua Tree National Park near the Cottonwood Visitor Center off Cottonwood Spring Road. The spring is a short walk down a dirt path from the parking area, providing an opportunity to see a wide range of plant and wildlife. This trailhead also provides access to longer hikes on the Mastodon Peak Loop and Lost Palms Oasis Trail. The Cottonwood Spring Wilderness Backpacking Board is located at the trailhead for backpackers to self register for overnight backpacking trips in the area.

properties.name: Cow Rock
properties.notes:
Cow Rock
https://www.nps.gov/places/cow-rock.htm

A rock formation that is shaped like a cow overlooking the Hidden Valley Trail. To find this rock formation while hiking the Hidden Valley Trail, stop at the Mountain Quail Interpretive Sign and look to the west. At the top of the tall wall of rocks is Cow Rock.

properties.name: Cyclops Rock
properties.notes:
Cyclops Rock
https://www.nps.gov/places/cyclops-rock.htm

Cyclops Rock is a large monzogranite rock formation along Barker Dam Road near Hidden Valley Campground. This formation is popular with rock climbers and known for the climbing problem called "The Eye". Looking up at Cyclops Rock you will see a hole near the top of the formation, this is the "Eye" of the cyclops.

properties.name: Desert Tortoise (Contact Mine)
properties.notes:
Desert Tortoise (Contact Mine) https://www.nps.gov/places/desert-tortoise-contact-mine.htm The Contact Mine Trail is an out-and-back hike to a historic mining site. It is 4-miles round trip with 700 feet of elevation gain. The trail begins in a sandy wash then ascends a rocky mountainside to the mine. The hike features expansive views of the surrounding mountains and a chance to view mining artifacts used a century ago. Do not handle or remove any historic artifacts from the site. 

This trail is a great option if you are looking to get away from the crowds and enjoy more solitude. After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. 

For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.

properties.name: Desert Tortoise (Silver Bell)
properties.notes:
Desert Tortoise (Silver Bell) https://www.nps.gov/places/desert-tortoise-silver-bell.htm

Look up near the top of the rocky hills southwest of this pullout. Spot Silver Bell Mine ruins, one of 300 mines once active in Joshua Tree National Park. The surrounding landscape is filled with creosote, desert lavender, bladderpod, and other shrubs. This section of the park is part of the transition zone between the Mojave and Colorado Deserts.

properties.name: Desert Tortoise (Wilson Canyon)
properties.notes:
Desert Tortoise (Wilson Canyon) https://www.nps.gov/places/desert-tortoise-wilson-canyon.htm

As you take in the views of Wilson Canyon, notice the differences between the Mojave Desert to the north and the Colorado Desert to the south. The Mojave Desert is higher in elevation and has Joshua trees, yuccas, and other desert plants. The Colorado Desert is lower in elevation and hotter. Here, you will find creosote bushes, desert lavender, and other flora adapted to the sandy soil. Wilson Canyon is part of the Transition Zone, where these two deserts meet.

properties.name: Deserts (Quail Springs)
properties.notes:
Deserts (Quail Springs)
https://www.nps.gov/places/deserts-quail-springs.htm

Quail Springs Picnic Area is the first picnic area along Park Boulevard when entering from the west entrance. Picnic tables and grills are nestled among Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs, next to large rock formations. The area also contains pit toilets and has trailheads for the Quail Springs Historic Trail and Ryan Johnnie Connector Trail, as well as, quick access to the Boy Scout Trail.

properties.name: Deserts (Silver Bell)
properties.notes:
Deserts (Silver Bell) https://www.nps.gov/places/deserts-silver-bell.htm

Look up near the top of the rocky hills visible from the pullout. Spot the remains of Silver Bell Mine, one of 300 mines once active in Joshua Tree National Park. The surrounding landscape contains creosote, desert lavender, bladderpod, and other shrubs. This section of the park is part of the transition zone between the Mojave and Colorado Deserts.

properties.name: Deserts (Turkey Flats)
properties.notes:
Deserts (Turkey Flats) https://www.nps.gov/places/deserts-turkey-flats.htm

Turkey Flats is a picturesque stop along Pinto Basin Road with a small parking area. It is a great place to take in sweeping panoramic views and see the contrast between the lower elevations and the higher elevations in the northwest region of the park. From the parking area, Pinto Mountain can be seen standing nearly 4,000 feet tall. The parking area includes an interpretive wayside sign educating visitors about the area.  

For those interested in astronomy, Turkey Flats is an ideal place for stargazing in Joshua Tree National Park due to its remote location and exceptionally dark skies.  
 
There are no established or maintained trails in the Turkey Flats area.

properties.name: Discovery Trailhead
properties.notes:
Discovery Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/discovery-trailhead.htm

The Discovery Trail is a 0.7-mile (1.1km) loop hike with 70ft (21.3m) of elevation gain and diverse views of the jumbo rocks area. Hike this trail through sandy washes, boulder piles, and unique rock formations. Along the trail, you will find educational signs that are great for learning more about the desert! There is also a vista point offering scenic views of jumbo rocks, skull rock, and elephant rock. This trail is nice choice for families looking for an easy and educational trail with light rock scrambling opportunities.  

 

The Discovery Trail begins across the street from Skull Rock. It connects to the Split Rock Trail and Face Rock. To access this trail, park near Skull Rock along Park Boulevard. The area can be congested so watch out for pedestrians while driving. When parking, watch out for deep sand, park completely off the road, and do not park on vegetation. When walking from your car to the trailhead, do not walk in the road and use the crosswalk when crossing.

properties.name: Echo T Trailhead
properties.notes:
Echo T Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/echo-t-trailhead.htm Take the Echo T Trail to connect to the Barker Dam Trail from the Echo T parking lot. This trail follows a wash near unique rock formations. Meander among Joshua trees and other desert plants. Watch for climbers or try to spot desert bighorn sheep. Get ready for a minor rock scramble before connecting to the Barker Dam Nature Trail.

Along this hike you may see evidence of Native American rock art or petroglyphs. Respect the art by not touching or climbing on it.

Hike Echo T Trail as an out and back for an easy 1.4 mile (2.5km) roundtrip hike. Adding the Barker Dam Nature Trail increases your total hiking distance to 2.5 miles (4.0km) roundtrip. 

After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.

properties.name: Ecology (Hidden Valley)
properties.notes:
Ecology (Hidden Valley)
https://www.nps.gov/places/ecology-hidden-valley.htm

Hidden Valley Picnic Area is a large spread out picnic area along Park Boulevard in the middle of the park. Located in an area of large rock formations with many Joshua trees, there are many picnic tables and grills available. The parking area and sidewalks with access to the pit toilets are paved while the areas around the picnic tables are flat dirt areas. The picnic area is a short walk from the Hidden Valley Trailhead.

properties.name: Elephant Rock near Skull Rock
properties.notes:
Elephant Rock near Skull Rock
https://www.nps.gov/places/elephant-rock-near-skull-rock.htm

Elephant Rock is a granite rock formation shaped like an elephant from the side view and can be seen from Park Boulevard. Elephant Rock is located south of Skull Rock near the parking spaces for Skull Rock and Discovery Trail Trailheads.

properties.name: Emergency Phone
properties.notes:
Emergency Phone https://www.nps.gov/places/emergency-phone.htm An emergency phone is located on the north side of the bathroom in the Intersection Rock parking lot.

Emergency first aid and medical care are available by using the emergency phone. If requesting help, please be prepared to report the nature of the emergency and the location or nearest landmark.

properties.name: End of Trail
properties.notes:
End of Trail
https://www.nps.gov/places/end-of-trail.htm

The end of the Hi-View Nature Trail.

properties.name: Eureka Peak Trailhead
properties.notes:
Eureka Peak Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/eureka-peak-trailhead.htm

Eureka Peak Trail is an 11 mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 1748 ft of elevation gain. Most of the hike is a slow gradual rise in a sandy wash surrounded with desert vegetation until the trail gets steeper near the summit. From the top, Eureka Peak offers a stunning 360-degree view of the surrounding mountains and valleys. Take in a view that not many visitors experience during a trip to Joshua Tree. Keep a look out for the elusive Desert tortoise and Bighorn sheep as they are sometimes seen in this area of the park! 

To begin, start hiking on the California Riding and Hiking Trail from the Black Rock Backcountry Trailhead. At the junction at 1.1 miles, take the Eureka Peak Trail and head south towards the peak. There are multiple options for parking. Park at the Black Rock Backcountry Trailhead or park at the Black Rock Nature Center. On busy days, there is additional overflow parking in the horse camp area.

properties.name: Face Rock
properties.notes:
Face Rock
https://www.nps.gov/places/face-rock.htm

Face Rock is a rock formation that resembles a side profile of a face. It is located on a spur trail off the Split Rock Loop Trail.

properties.name: Flash Floods (Porcupine Wash)
properties.notes:
Flash Floods (Porcupine Wash) https://www.nps.gov/places/flash-floods-porcupine-wash.htm

At Porcupine Wash, visitors can see smoke trees, desert willows, lavender bushes, and the desert life attracted to them. Not far along the route, a side trail leads to Ruby Lee Mill's ruin, established in 1935. Near the end of the wash, an unmaintained trail leads to the summit of Monument Mountain. Monument Mountain is the highest peak in the Hexie Mountains at 4,834 feet.

properties.name: Fortynine Palms Oasis
properties.notes:
Fortynine Palms Oasis https://www.nps.gov/places/fortynine-palms-oasis.htm

Fortynine Palms Oasis is one of Joshua Tree National Park's desert oases and is open to the public in the fall, winter, and spring. Located in the northern portion of the park, this oasis provides a refuge among the desert mountains. By providing a reliable source of water, this little oasis allows life to thrive in this seemingly harsh environment.

The oasis is reachable by the Fortynine Palms Oasis Trail, a three mile out and back hike with 300 feet elevation gain in each direction.

This oasis is a sensitive biological area, please follow posted signs and do not enter the oasis as this is a crucial water supply for plant and wildlife. 

In the summer, Fortynine Palms Oasis, its trail, and the parking area all close to allow bighorn sheep undisturbed access to surface water. The park is under drought conditions and herds in the area are increasingly reliant on the oasis spring to survive the hot summer months. The closure will remain in place until summer or fall monsoons provide adequate rainfall to increase water availability.

properties.name: Fortynine Palms Oasis Trailhead
properties.notes:
Fortynine Palms Oasis Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/fortynine-palms-oasis-trailhead.htm

Fortynine Palms Oasis Trailhead provides access to Fortynine Palms Oasis on a three mile out and back hike which is only open in the fall, winter and spring.The trail is on compact dirt with 300  feet of elevation gain in each direction.This trailhead is in a northern section of the park seperate from the rest of the park roads and is accessed by Canyon Road off of Highway 62 between Indian Cove and Twentynine Palms.

The trail is usually closed in the summer to allow bighorn sheep undisturbed access to surface water. The park is under drought conditions and herds in the area are increasingly reliant on the oasis spring to survive the hot summer months. The reopening date changes year to year and the summer closure remains in place until summer monsoons provide adequate rainfall to increase water availability.

properties.name: Gateway Communities (North Entrance)
properties.notes:
Gateway Communities (North Entrance) https://www.nps.gov/places/gateway-communities-north-entrance.htm The North Entrance Station is a small fee booth located where Utah Trail becomes Park Boulevard. Visitors can pay their entrance fees or buy a park pass here as they go into the park. Park rangers may also collect fees or check passes here as visitors drive or bike out of the park.

If there is no ranger present or the fee booth is closed, visitors can continue to drive into the park without showing their pass or paying the entrance fee unless a special circumstance closes the park roads, like a weather closure.

properties.name: Geology (Skull Rock)
properties.notes:
Geology (Skull Rock) https://www.nps.gov/places/geology-skull-rock.htm Skull Rock is a popular destination along Park Boulevard just east of Jumbo Rocks Campground. Formed over many millennia, water drops have slowly eroded two large holes into the rock to make the rock resemble a skull. Skull Rock can be reached by the Skull Rock Nature Trail just a short walk from the parking area.
The Skull Rock Nature Trail is a 1.7 mile loop that can be started from trailheads on either side of the road. The north side of the loop also provides access to the Discovery Trail. Both trails are dirt and rock, include stairs and steep sections, and have narrow locations.

properties.name: Geology Tour Road Intersection
properties.notes:
Geology Tour Road Intersection https://www.nps.gov/places/geo-tour-intersection.htm

Geology Tour Road is an 18-mile motor tour leads through one of Joshua Tree National Park's most fascinating landscapes. Driving the full length of the road takes approximately two hours to make the round trip. The road provides access to scenic pullouts, a few hiking trails, and some climbing access routes. In good weather, most passenger vehicles may access the first few miles of the Geology Tour Road. Watch for the sign marking the point beyond which a 4-wheel-drive vehicle is recommended, and turn around there if your vehicle is not capable of handling deep ruts and soft sand. The road is not suitable for campers, trailers, and motor homes.

Road Info  

  • 18 miles (29 km) full round trip;
  • 5 miles (8 km) one way to Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k 
  • 4-wheel drive is recommended; high clearance necessary beyond Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k 
  • Expect soft sand and steep grades  
  • Off-road driving is prohibited  
  • Drive slowly and carefully; speed limit 25 mph (40 km/hour)  
  • One-way travel after  Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k  

Safety Info  

  • No food, water, gas, cell phone service or restrooms beyond this point  
  • Use caution near abandoned mines — stay out and stay alive  
  • Leave wildlife, plants, rocks, and artifacts undisturbed  
  • Overnight camping on road is prohibited; backcountry camping by permit only  
  • Campfires are prohibited

properties.name: Hall of Horrors
properties.notes:
Hall of Horrors https://www.nps.gov/places/hall-of-horrors.htm

Hall of Horrors is a popular location on the northwest side of Park Boulevard about halfway between Ryan Campground and Sheep Pass Group Campground. Hall of Horrors has several rock formations that can be explored on dirt paths and is a popular destination for scrambling and rock climbing. This area is also surrounded by mountains and provides many scenic views. If you want to explore the area on foot, please use the existing climber access paths to minimize your impact.

properties.name: Heart Rock
properties.notes:
Heart Rock
https://www.nps.gov/places/heart-rock.htm

Heart rock is a naturally formed granite boulder located off of a spur trail from the arch rock trail. Parking is available at the Twin Tanks parking lot.

properties.name: Hemingway
properties.notes:
Hemingway https://www.nps.gov/places/hemingway.htm

Hemingway is a popular location along Park Boulevard northwest of Hidden Valley. This pull-off contains many rock formations to explore, climbing routes for rock climbers, and scenic views of the surrounding mountains. Many large Joshua trees can also be found in this area. If you want to explore the area on foot, please use the existing climber access paths to minimize your impact.

properties.name: Hi-View Trailhead
properties.notes:
Hi-View Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/hi-view-trailhead.htm

The Hi-View Trailhead provides access to several trails in the northwest corner of the park. The trailhead is located down a dirt road northwest of Black Rock Campground. Some of the more popular hikes include the Hi-View Trail, an easy 1.3 mile loop, and West Side Loop, a moderate 4.1 mile loop that can be combined with additional trails for longer hikes. The trails in this area are a mix of dirt, rock, and sandy washes. All Black Rock Area Hiking Trails are considered moderate or strenuous and require decent navigation skills. 

The parking area for this trailhead is a small dirt parking lot so anything larger than a small RV (20 feet) may have difficulty turning around.

properties.name: Hidden Valley Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Hidden Valley Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/hidden-valley-picnic-area.htm

Hidden Valley Picnic Area is a large spread out picnic area along Park Boulevard in the middle of the park. Located in an area of large rock formations with many Joshua trees, there are many picnic tables and grills available. The parking area and sidewalks with access to the pit toilets are paved while the areas around the picnic tables are flat dirt areas. The picnic area is a short walk from the Hidden Valley Trailhead.

properties.name: Hidden Valley Trailhead
properties.notes:
Hidden Valley Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/hidden-valley-trailhead.htm

The Hidden Valley Trail is a one-mile loop hike through a scenic valley surrounded by large rock formations. The trail is excellent for families and offers exciting opportunities for rock scrambling. Along the trail are educational signs about local plants and animals. Between the late 1800s and early 1900s, the valley was used by cattle rustlers looking to stay “hidden”. As you hike the trail, look for Cow Rock, a cow-shaped rock formation on a wall overlooking the valley. 

The trail is considered easy but there are stairs and rock steps at the beginning and ending of the trail. This is a popular hike, and on busy days, the parking lot can fill up quickly. We recommend starting this hike by 9 am during busy weekends and holidays. Hidden Valley Trail has very little shade and no cell service. Before hiking, tell a safety buddy where you are going and when you plan on leaving the park.

properties.name: Homesteading (Ryan Ranch)
properties.notes:
Homesteading (Ryan Ranch) https://www.nps.gov/places/homesteading-ryan-ranch.htm

Ryan Ranch is a one-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with a 135-foot elevation gain. The trail travels along an old ranch road to a historic adobe structure at the base of Ryan Mountain. Ryan Ranch was built as a homestead in 1896 by J.D. Ryan, who operated the Lost Horse Mine. There are also remnants of past at the site such as a fallen windmill and old building materials. Do not remove any artifacts from the site. 

The Ryan Ranch Trail is a great place to discovery the park’s history while enjoying views of Ryan Mountain. This trail is typically less crowded than those close by and can offer peaceful solitude. 

You can access this trail from the parking area along Park Boulevard or from Ryan Campground near site 14.

properties.name: Indian Cove Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Indian Cove Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/indian-cove-picnic-area.htm

Indian Cove Picnic Area is located on the east side of the Indian Cove Campground. Picnic tables and grills are nestled among rock formations with scattered shrubs, Joshua trees, and small trees, providing a place for day visitors to enjoy a meal in the park.

properties.name: Indian Cove Ranger Station
properties.notes:
Indian Cove Ranger Station https://www.nps.gov/places/indian-cove-ranger-station.htm

The Indian Cove Ranger Station provides information on the Indian Cove section of Joshua Tree National Park. In addition to the Ranger Station, there is also a small picnic area, pit toilets, and the only water in the Indian Cover section of the park. There is also an emergency phone at the Indian Cove Ranger Station. 

Hours of operation may vary and are limited based on changing staffing availability.

properties.name: Indian Cove Trailhead
properties.notes:
Indian Cove Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/indian-cove-trailhead.htm

The Indian Cove Nature Trail Trailhead in located in Indian Cove in the northern section of the park. Beginning to the west of the Indian Cove Campground, this trailhead provides access to an easy .6 mile loop with minimal elevation gain and some steps along the way. Along the trail there are interpretive signs with information on the area.

After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.

properties.name: Indian Cove Wilderness Backpacking Board
properties.notes:
Indian Cove Wilderness Backpacking Board
https://www.nps.gov/places/indian-cove-wilderness-backpacking-board.htm

The Indian Cove Wilderness Backcountry Board is located at the beginning of the Lower Boy Scout Trail, aka the north end of the Boy Scout Trail in Indian Cove. This trailhead provides access to the Boy Scout Trail, which in turn connects to several other trails for longer hikes. The Boy Scout Trail runs eight miles, one way, between Indian Cove and Park Boulevard on dirt, rock, and sand surfaces. The backcountry board serves as a self registration point for backpacking along the Boy Scout Trail.

properties.name: Intersection Rock
properties.notes:
Intersection Rock https://www.nps.gov/places/intersection-rock.htm Intersection Rock is a large rock formation located near Hidden Valley Campground. It is the most climbed rock in the park, with over 40 climbing routes, and a great place to watch rock climbers in action. 

There is an emergency phone attached to the bathroom in the Intersection Rock parking area next to Hidden Valley Campground.

properties.name: Joshua Tree Sign
properties.notes:
Joshua Tree Sign
https://www.nps.gov/places/joshua-tree-sign.htm

As you approach the park from the south, this welcome sign marks the park boundary. Take a moment to admire the Colorado Desert and the surrounding mountains. A short drive north from the sign is the Bajada Nature Trail. Continuing north, you'll come across the Cottonwood Visitor Center, campground, and other amenities.

properties.name: Joshua Trees
properties.notes:
Joshua Trees https://www.nps.gov/places/joshua-trees.htm

Joshua trees (Yucca brevifolia) dominate much of the Black Rock area with their bright green leaves and spindly forms. These plants absorb as much water as possible after summer rains or winter snows through shallow roots that extend in a wide subterranean circle from their trunks. This leads to the fairly regular spacing of individual plants. Two Joshua trees growing near one another are likely the same individual, connected underground through networks of thin roots. Joshua trees store water in their trunks and branches, making them quite heavy during wet years and prone to tipping over or dropping branches. Take care not to climb on or attach ropes or hammocks to Joshua trees, despite their solid appearances they can be easily toppled.

properties.name: Joshua Trees (Geology Tour Road)
properties.notes:
Joshua Trees (Geology Tour Road) https://www.nps.gov/places/joshua-trees-geology-tour-road.htm

Geology Tour Road is an 18-mile motor tour leads through one of Joshua Tree National Park's most fascinating landscapes. Driving the full length of the road takes approximately two hours to make the round trip. The road provides access to scenic pullouts, a few hiking trails, and some climbing access routes. In good weather, most passenger vehicles may access the first few miles of the Geology Tour Road. Watch for the sign marking the point beyond which a 4-wheel-drive vehicle is recommended, and turn around there if your vehicle is not capable of handling deep ruts and soft sand. The road is not suitable for campers, trailers, and motor homes.

Road Info  

  • 18 miles (29 km) full round trip;
  • 5 miles (8 km) one way to Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k 
  • 4-wheel drive is recommended; high clearance necessary beyond Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k 
  • Expect soft sand and steep grades  
  • Off-road driving is prohibited  
  • Drive slowly and carefully; speed limit 25 mph (40 km/hour)  
  • One-way travel after  Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k  

Safety Info  

  • No food, water, gas, cell phone service or restrooms beyond this point  
  • Use caution near abandoned mines — stay out and stay alive  
  • Leave wildlife, plants, rocks, and artifacts undisturbed  
  • Overnight camping on road is prohibited; backcountry camping by permit only  
  • Campfires are prohibited

properties.name: Joshua Trees (Hemingway)
properties.notes:
Joshua Trees (Hemingway)
https://www.nps.gov/places/joshua-trees-hemingway.htm

Hemingway is a popular location along Park Boulevard northwest of Hidden Valley. This pull-off contains many rock formations to explore, climbing routes for rock climbers, and scenic views of the surrounding mountains. Many large Joshua trees can also be found in this area. If you want to explore the area on foot, please use the existing climber access paths to minimize your impact.

properties.name: Juniper Flats Backcountry Trailhead
properties.notes:
Juniper Flats Backcountry Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/juniper-flats-backcountry-trailhead.htm

The Juniper Flats Zone features open valleys, mountainous terrain, and panoramic views. It offers higher, cooler elevations ranging from ~4,400 to nearly 5,600 feet. During the colder months, freezing temperatures are common.

The Juniper Flats Backcountry Trailhead is the starting point for the following hikes:

  • Big Trees (6 miles)

  • Stubbe Springs (12 miles)


Visitors can also access the California Riding and Hiking Trail at this trailhead.

Find detailed information on each trail in the Hiking section on the app's homepage.

properties.name: Keys Ranch
properties.notes:
Keys Ranch https://www.nps.gov/places/keys-ranch.htm

Keys Ranch was built in 1910 and lived in by William and Frances Keys along with their children for over 60 years. Having first moved to the desert in search of gold, William Keys started this ranch as he built up a life for himself with mining and ranching. In 1917, Frances married and joined William at the ranch where they started a family and continued to build up the ranch. By not letting anything go to waste and figuring out how to reuse old parts they were able to build a prosperous ranch and mining operation in a seemingly hostile environment.

Keys Ranch is only open to guided ranger led tours that require advance registration. Check the park website for additional information on visiting Keys Ranch..

properties.name: Keys View
properties.notes:
Keys View https://www.nps.gov/places/keys-view.htm

Keys View provides wide panoromic views of the southern side of Joshua Tree National Park. Perched in the Little San Bernardino Mountains, Keys View offers exceptional views of the mountains as they flow into the Coachella Valley below. On a very clear day, it is even possible to see Signal Mountain in Mexico 90 miles to the south.

From the parking area you can enjoy the .25 mile paved Keys View Nature Trail for more views as well as educational wayside signs along the trail.

properties.name: Keys West Wilderness Backpacking Board
properties.notes:
Keys West Wilderness Backpacking Board
https://www.nps.gov/places/keys-west-wilderness-backpacking-board.htm

The Keys West Backcountry Board is located at the Upper Boy Scout Trail, aka the south end of the Boy Scout Trail, along Park Boulevard. This trailhead provides access to the Boy Scout Trail and Willow Hole Trail. The backcountry board serves as a self registration point for backpacking along the Boy Scout Trail.

properties.name: Leaving the Park (play as you drive out)
properties.notes:
Leaving the Park (play as you drive out)
https://www.nps.gov/places/leaving-the-park-play-as-you-drive-out.htm

Quail Springs Picnic Area is the first picnic area along Park Boulevard when entering from the west entrance. Picnic tables and grills are nestled among Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs, next to large rock formations. The area also contains pit toilets and has trailheads for the Quail Springs Historic Trail and Ryan Johnnie Connector Trail as well as quick access to the Boy Scout Trail.

properties.name: Little San Bernardino Mountains
properties.notes:
Little San Bernardino Mountains https://www.nps.gov/places/little-san-bernardino-mountains.htm

The High View Nature Trail is in the northern foothills of the Little San Bernardino Mountains, which stand between the Morongo Basin to the north and the Coachella Valley to the south. The Little San Bernardino Mountains are part of the Transverse Ranges, a group of mountains that formed along the San Andreas Fault as the North American and Pacific tectonic plates grind past one another. The higher elevations, as well as the proximity to the San Bernardino Mountains, means that this area generally has the highest quantity of precipitation and experience the coolest temperatures of anywhere in Joshua Tree National Park.

properties.name: Live Oak Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Live Oak Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/live-oak-picnic-area.htm

Live Oak Picnic Area is nestled among rock formations along Park Boulevard about two miles west of its intersection with Pinto Basin Road. This picnic area provides a day use area with picnic tables and grills for people that want to enjoy a meal in the park.

properties.name: Lost Horse Loop Trailhead
properties.notes:
Lost Horse Loop Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/lost-horse-loop-trailhead.htm

Lost Horse Loop is a 6.2-mile loop trail that combines natural beauty and historical interest. Visitors can enjoy the scenic views of Lost Horse Valley and visit a historic mining site. 

Lost Horse Mine operated between 1893 and 1936, producing over 9,000 ounces of gold. It was one of the most profitable mines within the park boundaries. At the mine, stay outside the fenced area and do not take any historic items  

Lost Horse Loop also provides an opportunity to see bighorn sheep. The Desert bighorn sheep are sometimes found in the rocky terrain near the Lost Horse trail. If you see any sheep, please keep a respectful distance. 

There is very little shade on this strenuous hike. It is not recommended in the summer heat. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection. Visitors seeking a shorter trail can hike to Lost Horse Mine out and back instead of completing the loop.

properties.name: Lost Horse Mine
properties.notes:
Lost Horse Mine https://www.nps.gov/places/lost-horse-mine.htm

Lost Horse Mine was one of the few successful mining operations of the more than 300 mines in what is now Joshua Tree National Park. The mining rights were originally purchased by Johnny Lang for $1,000. Realizing for safety that he needed more people in such a remote location, Lang brought in three partners before they were ultimately bought out in 1895 by J.D. Ryan, a wealthy rancher from Montana. From 1894 to 1931 the mine produced more than 10,000 ounces of gold and 16,000 ounces of silver (worth approximately $5 million today).

According to legend, the day shift was producing significantly more than the night shift so Ryan hired a private investigator to figure out what was happening. Upon discovering that Lang was pocketing half the ore for himself, Ryan forced Lang to decide between selling out or going to jail. Ultimately Lang sold his share and moved his prospecting to a nearby canyon.

In 1905, miners hit a fault and lost the vein of ore forever. Over the next couple of decades the mine changed hands several times and went through long periods of inactivity before ultimately becoming a part of Joshua Tree National Monument in 1936.

Today, the Lost Horse Mine can be reached on the Lost Horse Mine Loop Trail as part of a four mile out and back hike with 550 feet of elevation or as part of a longer loop for those that want a longer hike. Fences have been placed around the mine for safety, do not try to cross the fence and enter the mine as the area is unstable. Historic structures may seem safe but can easily crumble under a person's weight. Do not be fooled by appearances! Lost Horse Mine is a unique place and an important part of Joshua Tree's history. Please protect this place and report graffiti and other vandalism to JOTR_Graffiti@nps.gov.

properties.name: Lost Horse Mine Trailhead
properties.notes:
Lost Horse Mine Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/lost-horse-mine-trailhead.htm

The Lost Horse Mine trail is a 4-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 550 feet of elevation gain. Lost Horse Mine operated from 1893 to 1936, producing over 9,000 ounces of gold. It was one of the most successful mines in the Joshua Tree National Park area. Stay outside the fenced area to protect the mill site and mine when exploring near the mine.  

For a longer hike, continue on the Lost Horse Loop, a 6.2-mile loop hike with 1292 ft of elevation gain. There is very little shade, so it is not recommended in the summer heat. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.

properties.name: Lost Palms Oasis
properties.notes:
Lost Palms Oasis https://www.nps.gov/places/lost-palms-oasis.htm

Lost Palms Oasis is located in the southeastern portion of Joshua Tree National Park. This oasis can be reached on a 7.5 mile out and back hike from Cottonwood Spring with 500 feet of elevation gain. The trail is on a mix of rock, dirt, and sandy washes with very little shade and includes a strenuous climb on rocky terrain out of the canyon that the oasis is located in at the far end of the trail. The oasis is located in Lost Palms Canyon where a permanent water source allows fan palms and other plants to thrive, supporting a vibrant desert wildlife community.

properties.name: Lost Palms Oasis Trailhead
properties.notes:
Lost Palms Oasis Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/lost-palms-oasis-trailhead.htm

The Lost Palms Oasis Trail is a 7.5-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 500 feet of elevation gain. The trail leads through a diverse landscape of sandy washes and rocky mountainous terrain, and ends at Lost Palms Oasis, one of five fan palm oases in the park. The oasis is a refuge for a variety of birds and mammals, including the occasional bighorn sheep. Water, food, and shelter attract animals to this unique ecosystem.   

This hike is great for those looking for a longer day hike and opportunities to see wildlife.  

The trail is considered challenging because of its length and the strenuous climb out of the oasis. It has very little shade and is not recommended in the summer heat. Bring adequate food and water supplies, and wear sun protection.

properties.name: Lucky Boy Loop Trailhead
properties.notes:
Lucky Boy Loop Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/lucky-boy-loop-trailhead.htm

Lucky Boy Loop is a 3.25-mile hike with 555 ft of elevation gain. This loop leads hikers through diverse scenery of desert vegetation, rock formations, vista points, and the remains of Elton Mine. Look out for wildlife including scrub jays fluttering in the Pinyon pines, lizards basking on the rocks, and cottontails hiding in the shrubs. If you’re lucky, you may even spot a desert tortoise making its way across the landscape or eating some of the springtime wildflowers. The last section of the loop is .5 mile along the dirt Desert Queen Mine Road back to the Pine City parking lot. Keep an eye out for passing vehicles. 

 

This trail is not recommended in the summer heat, due to it’s length and lack of shade. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.

properties.name: Malapai Hill Viewpoint Parking Area
properties.notes:
Malapai Hill Viewpoint Parking Area https://www.nps.gov/places/malhill.htm

Construction by Destruction 

Unlike the incremental changes caused by weathering and erosion, some geologic process have changed Joshua Tree’s landscape in short, violent events.  

Malapai Hill 

Volcanic Origins: Standing tall above Queen Valley to the west, the hard, black basalt of Malapai Hill weathers and erodes slowly. This volcano is much younger than the surrounding monzogranite and likely formed within the past 15 million years. 

Blue Cut Fault 

Ancient Earnt Valley: Located to the south southwest, there has not been an earthquake on this fault in the last 8,000 years, but it is still active and could generate a moderate earthquake. One of many fault lines in the park, the Blue Cut Fault extends for over 50 miles (80 km) through the heart of the park. Earthquakes on this fault have resulted in over four miles of offset over the last few million years, with the north side of the fault moving west and the south side moving to the east and the uplift of the Hexie Mountains along the northern edge of Pleasant Valley.

Exploration Area  

Explore the ancient remnants of a volcano with desert views —hike to the top of Malapai Hill or around its base. Do not attempt during high temperatures. 

Glossary 

Erosion: A geological process in which natural forces such as wind or water move natural materials like rocks, dirt, and sand.  

Weathering: natural process when water, wind, heat, plants and other forces, slowly break or change the rock. 

Basalt: A dark fine-grained volcanic (i.e. igneous) rock.  

Uplift: The elevation of the Earth’s crust. Usually referring to tectonic uplift caused by slowly moving plates that cause earthquakes and changes to the earth’s surface.

properties.name: Mastodon Peak Trailhead
properties.notes:
Mastodon Peak Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/mastodon-peak-trailhead.htm Mastodon Peak is a moderate three mile loop with 375 feet of elevation gain. This hike starts from the Cottonwood Spring Oasis parking lot and starts on the Lost Palms Oasis Trail by Cottonwood Spring before splitting off to the left on the Mastodon Peak Loop. This hike provides great views of the southern portion of the park and includes an option scramble up to the top of the craggy granite peak.

This hike can be combined with the Lost Palms Oasis Trail for a longer hike.

This trail has no shade and no cell service. Always check the weather forecast before heading into the park and consider changing plans if the weather conditions are too extreme. Before hiking, tell a safety buddy where you are going and when you plan on leaving the park. Summer hikers should start this trail before 9 am and bring plenty of water.

properties.name: Maze Loop Trailhead
properties.notes:
Maze Loop Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/maze-loop-trailhead.htm

Hike this 5-mile loop trail with an elevation gain of 400 ft. and be led through a maze of Joshua Tree National Park’s famous granite rock formations. Start the hike in a sandy wash before meandering through boulder piles and Joshua tree woodlands. Look above and you might find large ravens or a hawk flying overhead. Watch below and there may be cottontail rabbits, lizards, or the occasional desert tortoise traveling across the landscape. 

Hikers can connect to other trails via Maze Loop including North View Trail and Big Pines Trail. Expect steep sections and pay close attention to trail markers. Some sections of the trail may be hard to identify between washes and social trails. Use the app’s integrated map to help you navigate.  
 

This trail is not recommended in the summer heat, due to it’s length and lack of shade. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.

properties.name: Minerva Hoyt (Minerva Hoyt Trail)
properties.notes:
Minerva Hoyt (Minerva Hoyt Trail) https://www.nps.gov/places/minerva-hoyt-minerva-hoyt-trail.htm The Minerva Hoyt Trail is an out-and-back hike to the Hidden Valley picnic area. It is 3 miles roundtrip with 100 feet of elevation gain. From the parking lot, the trail follows an old road before it takes a sharp right towards Hidden Valley. The hike goes through a valley of Joshua trees with excellent views of unique rock formations and mountains in the distance. It can be combined with the 1-mile Hidden Valley Nature Trail to create a 4-mile “lollipop” loop.  

The trail is named after Minerva Hoyt, the founding force behind Joshua Tree National Park. She lobbied congress and President FDR to preserve the area. Her efforts helped the park become designated as a National Monument in 1936. It later became a National Park in 1994.

After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.

properties.name: Minerva Hoyt Trailhead
properties.notes:
Minerva Hoyt Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/minerva-hoyt-trailhead.htm The Minerva Hoyt Trail is an out-and-back hike to the Hidden Valley picnic area. It is 3 miles roundtrip with 100 feet of elevation gain. From the parking lot, the trail follows an old road before it takes a sharp right towards Hidden Valley. The hike goes through a valley of Joshua trees with excellent views of unique rock formations and mountains in the distance. It can be combined with the 1-mile Hidden Valley Nature Trail to create a 4-mile “lollipop” loop.  

The trail is named after Minerva Hoyt, the founding force behind Joshua Tree National Park. She lobbied congress and President FDR to preserve the area. Her efforts helped the park become designated as a National Monument in 1936. It later became a National Park in 1994.

After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.

properties.name: Mining History (Juniper Flats)
properties.notes:
Mining History (Juniper Flats) https://www.nps.gov/places/mining-history-juniper-flats.htm

The Juniper Flats Zone features open valleys, mountainous terrain, and panoramic views. It offers higher, cooler elevations ranging from ~4,400 to nearly 5,600 feet. During the colder months, freezing temperatures are common.

The Juniper Flats Backcountry Trailhead is the starting point for the following hikes:

  • Big Trees (6 miles)

  • Stubbe Springs (12 miles)


Visitors can also access the California Riding and Hiking Trail at this trailhead.

Find detailed information on each trail in the Hiking section on the app's homepage.

properties.name: Musical Connection (Cap Rock)
properties.notes:
Musical Connection (Cap Rock)
https://www.nps.gov/places/musical-connection-cap-rock.htm

Cap Rock is a popular rock formation in the central part of Joshua Tree National Park. Located near the north end of Keys View Road near Park Boulevard, Cap Rock is an easy to reach location. In addition to the unique rock formation, Cap Rock offers a picnic area with grills as well as the Cap Rock Nature Trail for a short walk through nearby rock formations with interpretive signs along the way to learn about the area. The area around Cap Rock and the nature trail are flat dirt and gravel surfaces.

properties.name: Nolinas - Not Yuccas
properties.notes:
Nolinas - Not Yuccas https://www.nps.gov/places/nolinas-not-yuccas.htm

Parry’s nolina (Nolina parryi) is a hardy desert plant with long, thin, flexible leaves that make it easy to tell apart from Joshua trees or yuccas. In the spring, nolinas can grow a very tall flower stalk-- up to 12 feet tall! The flowers are cream colored and appear like a cone of popcorn on top of the stalk. Nolinas are slow growing plants that can live to be hundreds- possibly even over 1,000 years old.

properties.name: North Entrance Station
properties.notes:
North Entrance Station https://www.nps.gov/places/north-entrance.htm The North Entrance Station is a small fee booth located where Utah Trail becomes Park Boulevard. Visitors can pay their entrance fees or buy a park pass here as they go into the park. Park rangers may also collect fees or check passes here as visitors drive or bike out of the park.

If there is no ranger present or the fee booth is closed, visitors can continue to drive into the park without showing their pass or paying the entrance fee unless a special circumstance closes the park roads, like a weather closure.

properties.name: North View Trailhead
properties.notes:
North View Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/north-view-trailhead.htm

The North View Trail is a 5.6 mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 836 ft. of elevation gain. It can be made into a loop hike by connecting with the Maze Loop Trail or Window Loop Trail.  

North View Trail offers sweeping valley views of Joshua Tree National Park and the Morongo Basin. You’ll trek through valleys between towering boulder, sandy washes, rocky ridges and landscapes scattered with Joshua trees and native desert cacti. There are two short spur trails that lead to the viewpoints of Copper Mountain and Western Hills. 

Expect steep sections and pay close attention to trail markers. Use the app’s integrated map to help you navigate. This trail is not recommended in the summer heat, due to it’s length and lack of shade. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.

properties.name: Oaks and Pines
properties.notes:
Oaks and Pines https://www.nps.gov/places/oaks-and-pines.htm

While common in the Black Rock Canyon area, mature stands of pine and oak trees like these are relatively rare in Joshua Tree National Park. These species prefer a slightly cooler climate and are therefore confined to the higher elevations of the Little San Bernardino Mountains. Pinyon pine trees (Pinus pinaceae) are of particular concern to scientists as changing climate threatens the existence of this species in its current range.

properties.name: Oasis of Mara
properties.notes:
Oasis of Mara https://www.nps.gov/places/oasis-of-mara.htm

The Oasis of Mara is the easiest to reach oasis in Joshua Tree National Park. Located near the Joshua Tree National Park headquarters in the town of Twentynine Palms, this oasis is reached by a short and level paved path. The water from this oasis supports a vibrant plant and wildlife community, including a cluster of California fan palms, making this a good location for viewing desert plant and wildlife. 

The Oasis of Mara has also long supported human life in the area. Named "Mara", meaning "the place of little springs and much grass" by the Serrano, this oasis is believed to be their first home in this world. According to their traditions, the fan palms at this oasis were first planted for every boy born in the village. The water of this oasis was able to support a village to live in the desert by providing the necessary water for the plants needed for food and materials to make items such as baskets, sandals, and homes.

properties.name: Oasis of Mara Trailhead
properties.notes:
Oasis of Mara Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/oasis-of-mara-trailhead.htm

The Oasis of Mara Trail is a peaceful, 0.5-mile paved trail that winds around a fan palm oasis. The trail is great for visitors looking for an easy stroll and offers a fantastic opportunity for birdwatching. Watch for common birds such as cactus wren, phainopepla, and Gambel's quail. Along the trail are educational signs about Native American history, knowledge, and modern connection to the area.  

Among the five fan palm oases in Joshua Tree National Park, the Oasis of Mara is one of the easiest to visit and see. The trailhead is located at park headquarters in Twentynine Palms, CA. The trail is wheelchair accessible and stroller friendly. 

To learn more about the Oasis of Mara, click here.

properties.name: Ocotillo (Ocotillo Patch)
properties.notes:
Ocotillo (Ocotillo Patch)
https://www.nps.gov/places/ocotillo-ocotillo-patch.htm

Ocotillo Patch is a scenic pull off along Pinto Basin Road located between two mountain ranges in an alluvial fan, a place where sediments spread out from a narrow area, often carried by water. This area gets more moisture from runoff to support more plants, including the high number of ocotillo that are located here. This pull off includes an interpretive display as well as sweeping panoromic views of the area.

properties.name: Ocotillo Patch
properties.notes:
Ocotillo Patch
https://www.nps.gov/places/ocotillo-patch.htm

Ocotillo Patch is a scenic pull off along Pinto Basin Road located between two mountain ranges in an alluvial fan, a place where sediments spread out from a narrow area, often carried by water. This area gets more moisture from runoff to support more plants, including the high number of ocotillo that are located here. This pull off includes an interpretive display as well as sweeping panoromic views of the area.

properties.name: Orientation (Cottonwood Visitor Center)
properties.notes:
Orientation (Cottonwood Visitor Center)
https://www.nps.gov/places/orientation-cottonwood-visitor-center.htm

Located on Pinto Basin Road, approximately 7 miles north of Interstate 10 (exit 168), the Cottonwood Visitor Center is a convenient stop for those entering and exiting the park from the south. It has educational exhibits, a bookstore, visitor resources, and restroom facilities. You can grab a park map, buy an entrance pass, fill up your water bottle, and chat with a park ranger to get all your questions answered.

properties.name: Orientation (JTVC)
properties.notes:
Orientation (JTVC)
https://www.nps.gov/places/orientation-jtvc.htm

Located in downtown Joshua Tree just five miles from the West Entrance, the Joshua Tree Visitor Center offers educational exhibits, a bookstore, and visitor resources. Grab a park map, buy an entrance pass, and chat with a park ranger to get all your questions answered before heading into the park!

properties.name: Orientation (Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center)
properties.notes:
Orientation (Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center)
https://www.nps.gov/places/orientation-joshua-tree-national-park-visitor-center.htm

The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located in downtown Twentynine Palms and features educational exhibits, a bookstore and giftshop, and visitor information.

properties.name: Oyster Bar
properties.notes:
Oyster Bar https://www.nps.gov/places/oyster-bar.htm

Oyster Bar is a popular rock formation on the south side of Park Boulevard between Ryan Campground and Ryan Mountain. The parking area offers scenic views of the surrounding desert and mountains as well as access to climbing routes. If you would like to explore the rock formations by foot please use existing climber access routes to minimize your impact.

properties.name: Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k
properties.notes:
Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k https://www.nps.gov/places/paackuvuhuk.htm

Ever-changing Landscape 

This area wasn’t always a desert. As recent at 12,000 years ago, lush green vegetation covered the valleys and mountain slopes around you. Streams once fed a seasonal lake that is now the dry playa you just drove across. 

Changing Climate 

Pleistocene Epoch: Until 12,000 years ago, the climate in this region was much cooler and wetter. Thick soils anchored by lush vegetation covered rolling hills and slopes and water flowed through year-round streams. 

Present Day: At the end of the Pleistocene, the climate dried out and warmed up. The vegetation that was adapted to a wetter climate died, leaving behind bare slopes that are more vulnerable to erosion. Valley floors filled with sediment, creating the flat plains you see today. These plains are preserved because there isn't enough running water to erode them away. 

Changing Landscape 

Look for the following features to see evidence of an ever-changing landscape.  

Bajada: Find bajadas where alluvial fans merge to form a vast sediment slope at the mouth of canyons. 

Pediment: These sloping bedrock surfaces covered by gravel can be seen along the edges of mountains.  

Dry Wash: Washes transport sediment downhill. The smallest, lightest particles are carried farthest. Desert washes fill with rushing water after rain and monsoons. The washes in Joshua Tree spend most of the year dry.  

Playa: Streams carried sediment into a now dry lake. Clay and silt deposits are hundreds of feet deep here. 

Exploration Area 

Explore the desert surrounding you on foot. Notice the small details in the plants. Look for signs of animals. Take plenty of water with you. 

Glossary 

Alluvial fans: Alluvial comes from a Latin word, alluere meaning “to wash against”. Alluvial fans generally form where mountains meet the plains. A fast-running stream moving down a steep canyon can carry more sand, rocks, and pebbles, but when the water reaches the flat plains, it flows more slowly and can't carry the larger rocks and sand anymore. (Picture how fine silt settles out of a still lake, whereas a rushing river can push along sand, pebbles, and even large rocks.) These sediments accumulate in a fan shape at the mouth of canyons or washes. 

Bajada: A bajada is where many alluvial fans meet and converge.  

Pediment: A relatively flat or slightly concave surface of bedrock.

properties.name: Palm Oasis (Cottonwood Spring)
properties.notes:
Palm Oasis (Cottonwood Spring)
https://www.nps.gov/places/palm-oasis-cottonwood-spring.htm

Cottonwood Spring is a lush desert oasis located in the southern portion of the Joshua Tree National Park near the Cottonwood Visitor Center off Cottonwood Spring Road. The spring is a short walk down a dirt path from the parking area, providing an opportunity to see a wide range of plant and wildlife. This trailhead also provides access to longer hikes on the Mastodon Peak Loop and Lost Palms Oasis Trail. The Cottonwood Spring Wilderness Backpacking Board is located at the trailhead for backpackers to self register for overnight backpacking trips in the area.

properties.name: Panorama Loop Trailhead
properties.notes:
Panorama Loop Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/panorama-loop-trailhead.htm Hike up a sandy wash, then follow the ridgeline of the Little San Bernardino Mountains. Enjoy scenic views, dense Joshua tree forest, and pinyon-juniper woodland. This trail is 6.6 miles and has over a 1,000 feet of elevation gain. Warren Peak can be reached from a spur-trail off of the Panorama Loop. Bring a good map when hiking in the Black Rock area because there are many trails that crisscross and intersect. 

There are a few parking areas around the Black Rock Campground and Nature Center for hikers. Parking in the campground area can fill up on busy days. Hikers cannot park in a campsite unless they have reserved that campsite. To find the trailhead, hike south from the Black Rock Nature Center, in the uphill direction. At the end of the campground, find the trail sign for panorama loop and start up the washy trail. 

This trail has limited shade and unreliable cell service. Always check the weather forecast before heading into the park and consider changing plans if the weather conditions are too extreme. Hikers should always tell a safety buddy where they are going and when they plan on leaving the park.

properties.name: Park Overview (Joshua Tree Sign)
properties.notes:
Park Overview (Joshua Tree Sign)
https://www.nps.gov/places/park-overview-joshua-tree-sign.htm

As you approach the park from the south, this welcome sign marks the park boundary. Take a moment to admire the Colorado Desert and the surrounding mountains. A short drive north from the sign is the Bajada Nature Trail. Continuing north, you'll come across the Cottonwood Visitor Center, campground, and other amenities.

properties.name: Park Overview (North Entrance)
properties.notes:
Park Overview (North Entrance) https://www.nps.gov/places/park-overview-north-entrance.htm The North Entrance Station is a small fee booth located where Utah Trail becomes Park Boulevard. Visitors can pay their entrance fees or buy a park pass here as they go into the park. Park rangers may also collect fees or check passes here as visitors drive or bike out of the park.

If there is no ranger present or the fee booth is closed, visitors can continue to drive into the park without showing their pass or paying the entrance fee unless a special circumstance closes the park roads, like a weather closure.

properties.name: Peak Experience
properties.notes:
Peak Experience https://www.nps.gov/places/peak-experience.htm

The peak of the High View Nature Trail is 4,445 feet above sea level. To the northeast lies the community of Yucca Valley, and on clear days it is easy to see the distant expanse of the Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center, over 40 miles away. The peak of Mount San Gorgonio, to the west, is over 50 miles away. These stunning views are thanks partially to the high vantage point and lack of obstacles, and also because low humidity in desert air makes for easier long-range sightseeing.

properties.name: Pine City Trailhead
properties.notes:
Pine City Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/pine-city-trailhead.htm

Pine City Trailhead is located in the central portion of the park at the east end of Queen Valley Road. This trailhead provides access to the Pine City Trail and the Lucky Boy Vista Trail. The Pine City Trail is a four mile out and back mostly sand and level trail with occasional steep sections that makes its way through a dense stand of junipers and pinyon. Both of these trails can be combined with other trails for longer hikes. This trailhead also has the Pine City Wilderness Backpacking Board with backpacking information and self registration for backpackers.

properties.name: Prehistoric Animals (Pinto Basin Pullout)
properties.notes:
Prehistoric Animals (Pinto Basin Pullout) https://www.nps.gov/places/prehistoric-animals-pinto-basin-pullout.htm

Welcome to the Pinto Basin. This breathtaking landscape was once characterized by lush lakes, swamps, and verdant grasslands. Although it's drier now, it remains a thriving habitat for rare desert wildlife. Wildlife found here include sidewinder rattlesnake, the jackrabbit, and Mojave fringe-toed lizard.

For those interested in stargazing, the Pinto Basin is an ideal place in Joshua Tree. The Pinto Basin offers a remote location and exceptionally dark skies. If stargazing, stay awake and alert within 20 feet (6 meters) of your vehicle.

properties.name: Quail Springs Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Quail Springs Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/quail-springs-picnic-area.htm

Quail Springs Picnic Area is the first picnic area along Park Boulevard when entering from the west entrance. Picnic tables and grills are nestled among Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs, next to large rock formations. The area also contains pit toilets and has trailheads for the Quail Springs Historic Trail and Ryan Johnnie Connector Trail as well as quick access to the Boy Scout Trail.

properties.name: Rare Tree (Live Oak Picnic Area)
properties.notes:
Rare Tree (Live Oak Picnic Area) https://www.nps.gov/places/rare-tree-live-oak-picnic-area.htm

Live Oak Picnic Area is nestled among rock formations along Park Boulevard about two miles west of its intersection with Pinto Basin Road. This picnic area provides a day use area with picnic tables and grills for people that want to enjoy a meal in the park.

properties.name: Rock Climbing (Intersection Rock)
properties.notes:
Rock Climbing (Intersection Rock) https://www.nps.gov/places/rock-climbing-intersection-rock.htm Intersection Rock is a large rock formation located near Hidden Valley Campground. It is the most climbed rock in the park, with over 40 climbing routes, and a great place to watch rock climbers in action. 

There is an emergency phone attached to the bathroom in the Intersection Rock parking area next to Hidden Valley Campground.

properties.name: Ryan Mountain Trailhead
properties.notes:
Ryan Mountain Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/ryan-mountain-trailhead.htm

Ryan Mountain is a 3-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 1,050 feet of elevation gain. The summit rewards hikers with one of the best 360-degree views of any trail in the park. From the summit, you can see the Wonderland of Rocks, the Sheephole Wilderness, Mount San Jacinto towering over 10,000 feet above Palm Springs, and Mount San Gorgonio, the tallest peak in Southern California. If you are on the top on a clear day, you can even see all the way to Mexico! 

This trail also features the oldest rock type in the park – Pinto Gneiss. It is estimated to be 1.8 billion years old! It is distinguished by its striking light and dark stripes and is noticeably different than the lighter-colored monzogranite cliffs and boulders below.  

In addition to the views and interesting geology, Ryan Mountain is habitat for some of the park’s elusive wildlife – the Desert bighorn sheep. Keep an eye out for these magnificent animals during your ascent and descent.  

Due to its popularity, visitors should arrive early to secure a parking spot on busy days. Pack warm layers on cold and windy days, and always bring adequate food and water supplies and sun protection. This hike is not recommended in the summer due to extreme heat.

properties.name: Ryan Ranch Trailhead
properties.notes:
Ryan Ranch Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/ryan-ranch-trailhead.htm

Ryan Ranch is a one-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with a 135-foot elevation gain. The trail travels along an old ranch road to a historic adobe structure at the base of Ryan Mountain. Ryan Ranch was built as a homestead in 1896 by J.D. Ryan, who operated the Lost Horse Mine. There are also remnants of past at the site such as a fallen windmill and old building materials. Do not remove any artifacts from the site. 

The Ryan Ranch Trail is a great place to discovery the park’s history while enjoying views of Ryan Mountain. This trail is typically less crowded than those close by and can offer peaceful solitude. 

You can access this trail from the parking area along Park Boulevard or from Ryan Campground near site 14.

properties.name: San Gorgonio View
properties.notes:
San Gorgonio View https://www.nps.gov/places/san-gorgonio-view.htm

From this vantage point, on all but the foggiest days, the peak of Mount San Gorgonio is visible, rising from the San Bernardino Mountains and topping out at 11,503 feet above sea level. These mountains are the reason why this area is a desert. Moist air from the Pacific Ocean is pushed east by wind  towards Joshua Tree National Park, but the mountains are too large an obstacle for wet, heavy clouds, so most of the moisture is discharged before the clouds can make their way over to Joshua Tree. Precipitation on the west (ocean) side of the mountains can be more than double the precipitation on the eastern side.

properties.name: Short Loop Trailhead
properties.notes:
Short Loop Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/short-loop-trailhead.htm

This 4-mile loop hike passes through the hills, washes, ravines, and valleys east of the Black Rock Campground. It is a great hike for those camping in Black Rock or those looking to explore the quieter side of the park. 

Enjoy the scattered Joshua trees, Juniper trees, rabbitbrush, and the occasional pinyon pine. Keep an eye out for jackrabbits, lizards, and the rarely seen desert tortoise.  

Because this trail is located at a higher elevation than much of the park, it has slightly cooler temperatures on warm days. However, there is very little shade mid-day, so it is not recommended in the summer heat. Make sure to bring at least 2 liters of water and proper sun protection.  

 

There are multiple options for parking. Park at the Black Rock Backcountry Trailhead or park at the Black Rock Nature Center and start the trail near campsite 30. On busy days, there is additional overflow parking in the horse camp area.

properties.name: Skull Rock
properties.notes:
Skull Rock
https://www.nps.gov/places/skull-rock.htm

Skull Rock is a popular destination along Park Boulevard just east of Jumbo Rocks Campground. Formed over many millennia, water drops have slowly eroded two large holes into the rock to make the rock resemble a skull. Skull Rock can be reached by the Skull Rock Nature Trail just a short walk from the parking area.

properties.name: Skull Rock and Discovery Trail Trailheads
properties.notes:
Skull Rock and Discovery Trail Trailheads
https://www.nps.gov/places/skull-rock-and-discovery-trail-trailheads.htm
